McCain Continues Trump-Defying Ways; Opposes OMB Pick "... it would be irresponsible ..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., continued his recent pattern of being a thorn in the side of Donald Trump by announcing Wednesday he will vote against the president’s pick to head the Office of Management and Budget. 
Trump has chosen Rep. Mick Mulvaney, R-S.C., to fill the post. The congressman currently serves on the House Committee on Financial Services and is a budget hawk. 
McCain, who serves as chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said he opposes Mulvaney’s appointment because of his past opposition to increases in defense spending. Advertisement - story continues below President Trump Will Close Out Hectic Week With A Campaign Rally 
“Under most circumstances, I always give the benefit of the doubt to the incoming president … so it is with great reluctance that I came to the floor of the Senate to rise in opposition to the nomination of Mick Mulvaney,” McCain said . 
“[He] has spent his last six years pitting the national debt against our military,” the senator added. Advertisement - story continues below 
McCain went after Mulvaney for successfully offering an amendment that cut $3.5 billion from a defense appropriations bill in 2013. 
“President Trump has said that defense cuts over the last several years have depleted our military. Our military leaders have testified that these cuts have placed the lives of our military service members at greater risk. But Congressman Mulvaney has said that, in the greater scheme of things, sequestration cuts were not that big,” McCain stated. 
The U.S. defense budget in 2013 was approximately $530 billion, making up one-fifth of all federal spending. By comparison, the defense budget in 2001 — which was pre-9/11 — was $287 billion. 
The budget for the current fiscal year is $583 billion. Advertisement - story continues below
